title: Quine–Putnam indispensability argument
summary: The Quine–Putnam indispensability argument[lower-alpha 1] is an argument in the philosophy of mathematics for the existence of abstract mathematical objects such as numbers and sets, a position known as mathematical platonism. It was named after the philosophers Willard Quine and Hilary Putnam, and is one of the most-important arguments in the philosophy of mathematics. It is widely considered to be one of the best arguments for platonism.
